channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Israeli forces take control at Rafah crossing; How a Border Patrol agent sees his job
item.description: Israeli forces have taken control of the Gaza side of the Rafah crossing into Egypt. A U.S. Border Patrol agent explains how he sees his agency's mission.
item.content:encoded: Israeli forces have taken control of the Gaza side of the Rafah crossing into Egypt. A U.S. Border Patrol agent explains how he sees his agency's mission.
item.dc:creator: Suzanne Nuyen

item.title: How the government is trying to stop rogue brokers from plaguing ACA enrollees
item.description: Federal regulators are trying to prevent bad actors from switching unknowing consumers' Obamacare coverage. Their fixes risk making enrollment so cumbersome that people won't want to sign up.
item.content:encoded: Federal regulators are trying to prevent bad actors from switching unknowing consumers' Obamacare coverage. Their fixes risk making enrollment so cumbersome that people won't want to sign up.
item.dc:creator: Julie Appleby

item.title: How a U.S. Customs and Border Protection veteran sees his agency's mission
item.description: Ryan Riccucci, a 17-year agency veteran, says he feels the agency is misunderstood by the U.S. public.
item.content:encoded: Ryan Riccucci, a 17-year agency veteran, says he feels the agency is misunderstood by the U.S. public.
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: 5 workers dead, dozens still missing after a building collapsed in South Africa
item.description: Rescue teams worked searching for dozens of construction workers buried under the rubble after a multi-story apartment complex that was being built collapsed in a coastal city in South Africa.
item.content:encoded: Rescue teams worked searching for dozens of construction workers buried under the rubble after a multi-story apartment complex that was being built collapsed in a coastal city in South Africa.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Israeli forces take control of the Gaza side of the Rafah crossing with Egypt
item.description: An Israeli tank brigade seized control Tuesday of the Gaza Strip side of the Rafah border crossing with Egypt, authorities said, as cease-fire negotiations with Hamas remain on a knife's edge.
item.content:encoded: An Israeli tank brigade seized control Tuesday of the Gaza Strip side of the Rafah border crossing with Egypt, authorities said, as cease-fire negotiations with Hamas remain on a knife's edge.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: The history of 'outside agitators' â€” from Gaza protests to Martin Luther King Jr.
item.description:
The term "outside agitator" has staying power.

It's been used against protestors throughout history, from the Civil Rights Movement, to the anti-Vietnam War protests and now during the pro-Palestinian demonstrations on college campuses.

"Outside agitator" was also used to describe some of the people who protested the killing of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri In 2014.

Who exactly are the "outside agitators" and what purpose does it serve to call them out?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.
item.content:encoded:
The term "outside agitator" has staying power.

It's been used against protestors throughout history, from the Civil Rights Movement, to the anti-Vietnam War protests and now during the pro-Palestinian demonstrations on college campuses.

"Outside agitator" was also used to describe some of the people who protested the killing of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri In 2014.

Who exactly are the "outside agitators" and what purpose does it serve to call them out?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

(Image credit: Scott Olson)

item.title: The clock is ticking to fix Social Security as retirees face automatic cut in 9 years
item.description: Social Security's finances have improved slightly in the last year. But the popular retirement program still faces big challenges including the threat of automatic benefit cuts in less than a decade.
item.content:encoded:
Social Security's finances have improved slightly in the last year. But the popular retirement program still faces big challenges including the threat of automatic benefit cuts in less than a decade.

(Image credit: Kevin Dietsch)
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: 2024 Met Gala Red Carpet: Looks we love
item.description: Monday is the Met Gala, known as fashion's grandest event, where celebrities from various realms come together at New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art to celebrate fashion and each other.
item.content:encoded:
Monday is the Met Gala, known as fashion's grandest event, where celebrities from various realms come together at New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art to celebrate fashion and each other.

(Image credit: Angela Weiss)
item.dc:creator: Anastasia Tsioulcas

item.title: Transgender bathroom bills are back, gaining traction after past boycotts
item.description: Blowback from companies and institutions was fierce after North Carolina passed transgender bathroom restrictions. But states haven't felt as much heat after several bills easily passed.
item.content:encoded:
Blowback from companies and institutions was fierce after North Carolina passed transgender bathroom restrictions. But states haven't felt as much heat after several bills easily passed.

(Image credit: Rick Bowmer)
item.dc:creator: Deena Prichep

item.title: FAA is investigating Boeing for apparent missed inspections on 787 Dreamliner
item.description: The FAA says Boeing informed the agency in April that required inspections to confirm that the wings were properly bonded to the carbon fiber fuselage on certain 787 jets were not completed.
item.content:encoded:
The FAA says Boeing informed the agency in April that required inspections to confirm that the wings were properly bonded to the carbon fiber fuselage on certain 787 jets were not completed.

(Image credit: Logan Cyrus)
item.dc:creator: Russell Lewis
